page.title: 04Local History
page.content: The name Hawkshead denotes Viking occupation. The area became part of the lands of Furness Abbey in the C. XII. when the church dedicated to St. Michael and all angels and also the Old Court House, now a museum, were built. Hawkshead became a flourishing market town with a charter granted by James I. The school founded by Archbishop Sandys in 1585 is famous for its association with Wordsworth who was a pupil while lodging at Ann Tyson's cottage. The church contains interesting Restoration period wall paintings and parish registers dating from 1568. The Baptist chapel at Hawkshead Hill was founded in 1717 and the Friends' Meeting House at Colthouse dates from the late C. XVII. The whole area has been included in the itinerary of tourists to the Lake District since the 18th Century.
